what: Simon said in 1965 that "machines will be capable, within twenty years, of doing any work a man can do".
He predicted humans will be needed most in blue collar jobs and work where "face-to-face human interaction is of the essence".
ref: The shape of automation for men and management

what: A british mathematician that worked on cryptography with Alan Turing, I.J. Good predicted "[i]t is more probable than not that, within the twentieth century, an ultraintelligent machine will be built".
Good was optimistic about the aftermath, calling it an "intelligence explosion" (i.e. singularity) and in fact he believed humans' survival depends on inventing ultraintelligent AI.
ref: Speculations Concerning the First Ultraintelligent Machine

what: A cognitive and computer scientist, and also a co-founder of MIT's Artificial Intelligence lab, Marvin Minsky predicted AI would be able to replicate almost every aspect of intelligence within a generation (~20-30 years).

Although the wording was a little ambiguous, ("...few compartments of intellect will remain outside the machine's realm..."), he followed up with the claim that "the problems of creating 'artificial intelligence' will be substantially solved".

"I believe that the creation of greater than human intelligence will occur during the next thirty years...Just so I'm not guilty of a relative-time ambiguity, let me more specific: I'll be surprised if this event occurs before 2005 or after 2030."
